BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 21, 1921
A DEPLORABLE FACT
The fact, as revealed in a letter to the Mail-bag this week, that
group of Hopkins men was forced to admit its
representative
a
Mater" song when called upon for same in
"Alma
our
ignorance of
the presence of a number of other college men, is indeed deplorable.
The "Alma Mater" song is generally the dearest possession of a college man. It is, as a rule, this song which leaves the most lasting
impression on a graduate. When a number of old college chums get
together in after life it is not the "rah, rah" for them, but the spirited
"Alma Mater" which recalls the pleasant memories of the past.
It should not be considered a duty to learn "Veritas Vos Liberabit." It should be the desire of every man, from Freshman to
Senior, to learn this song as a matter of pride in his university. This
song is printed on page three of the Handbook and thus should be
easily accessible to every one. It might also be well to practice it
at one of the assemblies.

OUR BOTANICAL GARDENS
It may be well to call to the attention of the new students and,
perhaps, even the older students, the opportunities, apparently wholly
neglected, that lie in the availability of the Johns Hopkins Botanical
Gardens for pleasant and profitable personal research.
Even at this late season there, are curious plants, beautiful or
fantastical flowers, quaint specimens of shrubbery and strange water
plants in bloom, study of which will amply repay the student with
an idle half hour at his disposal. There are, for instance, cactus
plants, crimson dahlias, a weird lavender blossom from North China,
and plants with long, fuzzy white flower-spikes, with an unpronounceable name.
Many men seem to believe the gardens open only to students
of botany and allied sciences. Such, however, is not the case. The
walks are free to all. A fellow's sweetheart, one of these pleasant
autumn afternoons, might not be averse to a stroll through the gardens.
Of course, it should not be necessary to call attention to the rule
that visitors shall not handle or injure in any way any of the growing
things.

HELLO!
"The most cheerful, the most friendly word in the English language is 'hello'. It has brightened life for countless numbers. When
spoken at the right time it has been the turning point towards happiness and prosperity. It has promoted many lifelong friendships
and brought its own rewards. It is the magic symbol that turns
groups of men into one great brotherhood.
Realizing the great power of this word, the Student Council, last
year, inaugurated a 'Hello' movement in which every Stevens man
was asked to yell a hearty 'Hello!' to all the fellow Stevens men he
met. It was hoped that such a movement would bring about a closer
union of the Student Body, develop friendships, and promote a more
loyal, more active, and persistent college spirit. Needless to say, the
movement was very successful. Last winter and spring, the results
were evident in the way Stevens men greeted each other and in the
more hospitable spirit that prevailed throughout the campus."
Thus comments the "Stute" in an editorial.
A proposition was before the Hopkins Student Council last fall
to pass a Freshman regulation to the effect that "Freshmen should
speak to all Hopkins men on University grounds." This failed to
go through as the Council thought that there was an opportunity for
unreasonable Sophomores to treat the Freshmen unjustly.
There cannot be this objection, however, in making the movement voluntarily. The "Stute" commends it highly. Why shouldn't
it work at Hopkins? Start it going today and give every Hopkins
man you see a hearty "Hello !"

A DEPLORABLE FACT

To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
DEAR SIR: It is probable that if
all Hopkins students were requested
to sing their "alma mater," ninety
per cent. would be forced to acknowledge that they did not know
it.
This summer at Plattsburg, the
representatives of the various colleges present stood up, doffed hats,
and amid an impressive silence, began their "alma maters." College
after college responded. Finally,
someone called upon Hopkins. The
Hopkins delegation was forced to
admit that they did not know theirs.
No one said much, but in the attitude of the other college men we
could feel the question: "What
kind of a place is that, anyway?"
It is not as if Hopkins did not
have an "alma mater." She has,
and a beautiful one at that. This
has, however, for some unascertained reason, fallen into discard. If
the present one does not meet with
approval, why do not some of our
musical geniuses compose another
one? But by all means let the entire University learn some "alma
mater" at once and spare any further embarrassment to Hopkins
men in that respect.
Very sincerely yours,
PLATTSBURG.

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
DEAR SIR: There seems to be
considerable trouble about the
Freshmen wearing silk hose. The
rules in the Hand Book do not mention anything about this point. However, the Sophomores are trying to
add this rule. A pretty lively argument started between the Freshmen
and Sophs on Friday, when several

the presence of a number of other college men, is indeed deplorable.
The "Alma Mater" song is generally the dearest possession of a college man. It is, as a rule, this song which leaves the most lasting
impression on a graduate. When a number of old college chums get
together in after life it is not the "rah, rah" for them, but the spirited
"Alma Mater" which recalls the pleasant memories of the past.
It should not be considered a duty to learn "Veritas Vos Liberabit." It should be the desire of every man, from Freshman to
Senior, to learn this song as a matter of pride in his university. This
song is printed on page three of the Handbook and thus should be
easily accessible to every one. It might also be well to practice it
at one of the assemblies.

OUR BOTANICAL GARDENS
It may be well to call to the attention of the new students and,
perhaps, even the older students, the opportunities, apparently wholly
neglected, that lie in the availability of the Johns Hopkins Botanical
Gardens for pleasant and profitable personal research.
Even at this late season there, are curious plants, beautiful or
fantastical flowers, quaint specimens of shrubbery and strange water
plants in bloom, study of which will amply repay the student with
an idle half hour at his disposal. There are, for instance, cactus
plants, crimson dahlias, a weird lavender blossom from North China,
and plants with long, fuzzy white flower-spikes, with an unpronounceable name.
Many men seem to believe the gardens open only to students
of botany and allied sciences. Such, however, is not the case. The
walks are free to all. A fellow's sweetheart, one of these pleasant
autumn afternoons, might not be averse to a stroll through the gardens.
Of course, it should not be necessary to call attention to the rule
that visitors shall not handle or injure in any way any of the growing
things.

HELLO!
"The most cheerful, the most friendly word in the English language is 'hello'. It has brightened life for countless numbers. When
spoken at the right time it has been the turning point towards happiness and prosperity. It has promoted many lifelong friendships
and brought its own rewards. It is the magic symbol that turns
groups of men into one great brotherhood.
Realizing the great power of this word, the Student Council, last
year, inaugurated a 'Hello' movement in which every Stevens man
was asked to yell a hearty 'Hello!' to all the fellow Stevens men he
met. It was hoped that such a movement would bring about a closer
union of the Student Body, develop friendships, and promote a more
loyal, more active, and persistent college spirit. Needless to say, the
movement was very successful. Last winter and spring, the results
were evident in the way Stevens men greeted each other and in the
more hospitable spirit that prevailed throughout the campus."
Thus comments the "Stute" in an editorial.
A proposition was before the Hopkins Student Council last fall
to pass a Freshman regulation to the effect that "Freshmen should
speak to all Hopkins men on University grounds." This failed to
go through as the Council thought that there was an opportunity for
unreasonable Sophomores to treat the Freshmen unjustly.
There cannot be this objection, however, in making the movement voluntarily. The "Stute" commends it highly. Why shouldn't
it work at Hopkins? Start it going today and give every Hopkins
man you see a hearty "Hello !"

A DEPLORABLE FACT

To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
DEAR SIR: It is probable that if
all Hopkins students were requested
to sing their "alma mater," ninety
per cent. would be forced to acknowledge that they did not know
it.
This summer at Plattsburg, the
representatives of the various colleges present stood up, doffed hats,
and amid an impressive silence, began their "alma maters." College
after college responded. Finally,
someone called upon Hopkins. The
Hopkins delegation was forced to
admit that they did not know theirs.
No one said much, but in the attitude of the other college men we
could feel the question: "What
kind of a place is that, anyway?"
It is not as if Hopkins did not
have an "alma mater." She has,
and a beautiful one at that. This
has, however, for some unascertained reason, fallen into discard. If
the present one does not meet with
approval, why do not some of our
musical geniuses compose another
one? But by all means let the entire University learn some "alma
mater" at once and spare any further embarrassment to Hopkins
men in that respect.
Very sincerely yours,
PLATTSBURG.

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
DEAR SIR: There seems to be
considerable trouble about the
Freshmen wearing silk hose. The
rules in the Hand Book do not mention anything about this point. However, the Sophomores are trying to
add this rule. A pretty lively argument started between the Freshmen
and Sophs on Friday, when several
Sophs attempted to make a Freshman remove his silk socks. Now,
if it is the intention that the use of
silk hosiery should be forbidden,
wouldn't it not be well to give a
definite ruling on the subject so
that there may be no misunderstanding?
